content: ‚Ä¢ Forwards also are formatted inconsistently with replies, which is especially odd. Replies observe the client's color configuration and include signatures, albeit in odd places, while forwards contain no signature anywhere and contain a large number of elements, chiefly boxes, colored inconsistently with both dark and light modes. No means exists in Settings to configure either colors (specifically, generally, or to conform with the client's color mode configuration) or signatures for forwards.
creator: eb40

content:
If you post screenshots, people will be able to help you more.

Color settings are in Thunderbird settings > Composition.

This is the third post in which you have mentioned signatures in forwarded messages. See: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1553354
creator: mozilla98

content: Tolong bantuannya hp saya telah tersadap melalui web browser chrome
creator: reni.ana90

content:
eb40 said
Forwarded emails contain no signature, either above or below the forwarded email body. No means exists in settings to specify that a signature should be in forwarded emails. Thunderbird resists configuration for included signatures specified in the configuration editor.

Account settings > Composition & Addressing > Include signature for forwards

There's no need to use the configuration editor.
creator: mozilla98

content:
Nothing.

Probably the difficulty is that forwards and replies are formatted inconsistently in many ways and the client resists color configuration of reply text for forwards.

‚Ä¢ Neither replies nor forwards observe the dark mode configuration for the body of the email being replied to or forwarded. In both, it appears in quasi-light light mode with various elements appearing in red rectangles, instead of dark mode as in the email received. This is a gross rendering failure.

‚Ä¢ Furthermore, and quite oddly, forwards and replies inconsistently configure message text. The first failure is that replies are in dark mode and forwards are in light mode. The second failure is that message text in forwards is white, consistent with the dark mode scheme but not with white background, which is inconsistent with the dark mode scheme. The third failure is that the client resists configuration of message text to to any other color. So, perhaps a signature exists in the forwards but becase of this cascade of color configuration failures, is invisible.
creator: eb40

content:
There is a dividing line between the list of messages and the individual message that you see at the bottom. Click and drag that line to adjust the relative sizes of the top and bottom sections of the window. You can show more of the individual message so that the information is meaningful to you or you can choose not to show any part of an individual message at the bottom of the screen.

I put my dividing line in the middle.

To see more messages at once, you might also increase the size of your Thunderbird window. You might find that you have room for both many messages and part of an individual message. if you like that.

content:
Here's one approach that might be the simplest: import your csv with all the contacts to TB:

http://kb.mozillazine.org/Import_address_list_from_text_file

Select the imported address book in Address Book and click the New List button (right of the New Contact button). Name the list and close it. Select contacts in the address book (hold Shift or Ctrl to select multiples) and add them to the list by drag and drop onto the list icon. Repeat for other lists.

creator: aidan2

content: Try editing the csv in Excel before importing it ti TB. Set the columns to match the TB layout, i.e. columns labelled First Name, Last Name, Display Name, Nickname, Primary Email etc. This will make importing much easier as you don't have to move columns up or down in the import dialog. Once imported, confirm that the address book has the fields correctly filled in. After that, drag and drop should work.
creator: sfhowes

content:
Have you tried setting the security to STARTTLS, the standard on port 587?

When the connection is successful, you should get a prompt for the password, which is the same as for the incoming, and if you check the box to save it, an entry will be added to Saved Passwords.

If it still doesn't work, check that there's no antivirus or VPN blocking the connection.
creator: sfhowes

content: I have the port set to 587 and STARTTLS and saved the password and I still can not send emails. I just had to rebuild my laptop so there is no VPN or virus scan running. Is the password file saved by Thunderbird supposed to have an entry for both IMAP and SMTP servers? My password file only has and entry for IMAP server.
creator: bspitler004

content:
If you were able to check the box in the password prompt on sending, there should have been an smtp:// entry added to Saved Passwords with the same value as the imap:// entry.

Did you create a new profile after the rebuild or did you copy in an older profile?

Some users have security apps with password managers that can interfere with TB.
creator: sfhowes

content: I killed all processes for nordvpn and nordpass (password saver) and added a new email account and still only got IMAP entry in the password file. What do you mean by creating a new profile. I delete the existing email account and re-enter the server information. Any other suggestions are welcome. Thanks.
creator: bspitler004

content:
Previously you said there is "no VPN or virus scan running" but now there is apparently nordvpn and nordpass. Is the antivirus something other than Windows Security?

If the current profile was used in a previous TB setup, you could try adding the account to a new profile, starting from Help/Troubleshooting Info, about:profiles. To ensure there is no interference from VPN, password managers or antivirus, run Windows in safe mode.
creator: sfhowes

content: If the file with passwords was read-only, it wouldn't store the smtp entry, but the incoming password was apparently stored. If something like nordpass intercepts passwords, that could be a factor. Since the smtp password is the same as the incoming, it doesn't matter as long as the sending is successful.
creator: sfhowes

content: Yes the IMAP is updated but not the SMTP.

content: I uninstalled Thunderbird and deleted the email accounts. I deleted the Thunderbird folder in the Mozilla directory and rebooted. I reinstalled Thunderbird and added a new account. This time I was prompted to input the password for both the IMAP and the SMTP accounts. I am now able to send and receive emails. Thanks for all your help in this matter especially sfhowes. THANK YOU!
creator: bspitler004

content:
Please check your computer to see if you have got a VPN enabled. Many Anti-virus products now off a VPN and in some cases it's been auto enabled. Most servers do not like a VPN because it hides your IP address, so server thinks you might be a hacker. Server decides to protect your account and blocks access.

Maybe Anti-Virus is intervening as it scans any file that gets opened etc and causing an initial delay in connection, but soon after a connection is made.

Maybe you still have an old account trying to connect to a server.

  • Settings > Privacy & Security
  • Scoll to Passwords section
  • click on 'Saved Passwords'

Are there any references to any old accounts you have since removed ? If yes, select relevant lines and click on 'Remove'

Maybe you also have a Calendar or address book to another server eg: gmail Maybe that pop up is not for email, but for a calendar ?

creator: hajami

content:
If you already have the account in TB with Cox servers, it should be sufficient to change the incoming and outgoing settings to Yahoo's.

incoming: imap.mail.yahoo.com, 993, or pop.mail.yahoo.com, 995; SSL/TLS, OAuth2, email address

outgoing: smtp.mail.yahoo.com, 465, SSL/TLS, OAuth2, email address

Enter the account password in the OAuth window when asked to allow TB access.

https://help.yahoo.com/kb/mail/SLN36637.html
creator: sfhowes

content:
Are those greyed out folders also in italics ? If yes then they are 'no-select' folders. That means they cannot contain emails but can contain other folders which do contain emails.

Sometimes this can occur if you rename a folder.

I've found something in a bug report which may be same issue as yourself. Maybe you would want to follow it OR if you have some useful information please offer it. https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1997705
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
What are your settings? According to their site, they should be:

incoming POP server: pop.cybermesa.com, port 110, security = None, authentication = password, transmitted insecurely, User Name = part of address before @

outgoing SMTP server: smtp.cybermesa.com, port 587, security = None, authentication = password, transmitted insecurely, User Name = part of address before @

I don't think there should be a TLS error when the connection security is 'none'.
creator: sfhowes

content: Thank you for responding! I switched the the connection security back to 'none' and Thunderbird will still not link up with Cybermesa. I logged into the Cybermesa website to check if our password was correct and it logged in that way. When I tried putting the password into the pop-up through Thunderbird it still would not load.

creator: centinela78

content: McAfee is well-known to causes issues. I suggest you remove (not disable) it, at least temporarily, or run Windows in safe mode to bypass startup apps like antivirus. If TB works in Windows safe mode, you can either disable McAfee's action on TB (e.g. exclude the TB profile folder), or remove it permanently and use the built-in Windows Security (recommended).
